data.title: July Movie Releases
data.text:
JULY

July 1

THE BEACHES OF AGNèS An autobiographical documentary from one of the great figures in postwar French filmmaking, Agnès Varda, covering her early career as a photographer, her involvement in the emergence of the New Wave, her marriage to Jacques Demy and her feature films from “La Pointe-Courte” (1954) to “The Gleaners and I” (2000).

ICE AGE: DAWN OF THE DINOSAURS Sid the sloth (with the voice of John Leguizamo) finds a nest of dinosaur eggs while Scrat (Chris Wedge) the saber-toothed squirrel finds a love interest in this third installment of the computer-animated “Ice Age” franchise. With the voices of Ray Romano, Denis Leary, Seann William Scott, Queen Latifah and Simon Pegg; Carlos Saldanha directed. In 3-D in some theaters.

PUBLIC ENEMIES Michael Mann’s film recounts the early days of the F.B.I. with a focus on the agent Melvin Purvis (Christian Bale) as he attempts to put (and keep) John Dillinger (Johnny Depp) behind bars. Marion Cotillard, Channing Tatum, Giovanni Ribisi, Stephen Dorff, Billy Crudup and Leelee Sobieski co-star.

July 3

THE GIRL FROM MONACO When a repressed lawyer (Fabrice Luchini) gets in over his head with an aggressively sexual television weatherwoman (Louise Bourgoin), he turns to his bodyguard (Roschdy Zem) for help. Anne Fontaine (“Natalie”) directed this French feature.

July 10

BRüNO Sacha Baron Cohen poses as a gay Austrian fashion reporter and lures people into making fools of themselves in a new docu-comedy from the creators of “Borat.” Larry Charles directed.

HUMPDAY Afraid they’ve become too conventional, two straight male friends (Mark Duplass and Joshua Leonard) decide to make love on camera and enter the results in a Seattle film festival of amateur pornography. Lynn Shelton (“My Effortless Brilliance”) directed.

I LOVE YOU, BETH COOPER A socially impaired high school boy proclaims his hopeless love for the prettiest girl in class (Hayden Panettiere) and is given the night of his dreams as a reward. Chris Columbus directed from the novel by Larry Doyle, who also wrote the screenplay.

SOUL POWER Working from more than 12 hours of footage, Jeffrey Levy-Hinte has reconstructed a famous concert given in Kinshasa as a prelude to the Muhammad Ali-George Foreman “Rumble in the Jungle” of 1974. The performers include James Brown, Miriam Makeba, B. B. King and Celia Cruz.

YOO-HOO, MRS. GOLDBERG The documentarian Aviva Kempner, who looked at one symbol of New York Jewish life with her “Life and Times of Hank Greenberg,” turns her attention to another: Gertrude Berg, the creator and star of “The Goldbergs,” a pioneering sitcom on radio and television.

July 15

HARRY POTTER AND THE HALF-BLOOD PRINCE With the final battle with Voldemort fast approaching, Harry and his pals find themselves distractingly besieged by raging hormones. With Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, Emma Watson, Jim Broadbent, Helena Bonham Carter, Robbie Coltrane, Warwick Davis, Michael Gambon, Alan Rickman, Maggie Smith, Timothy Spall, David Thewlis and Julie Walters; David Yates directed.

SOMERS TOWN In a new film by Shane Meadows (“This Is England’), a teenage runaway (Thomas Turgoose) from England’s Midlands region befriends the son (Piotr Jagiello) of a Polish immigrant laborer; complications arise when both fall in love with a French waitress (Ireneusz Czop).

July 17

DEATH IN LOVE A Jewish woman (Jacqueline Bisset) has a relationship with a doctor in a Nazi death camp; half a century later, the effects are felt by her sons (Josh Lucas, Adam Brody and Lukas Haas). Boaz Yakin (“A Price Above Rubies”) directed.

(500) DAYS OF SUMMER When a shy copywriter for greeting cards (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) is dumped by his love-averse girlfriend (Zooey Deschanel), he reviews the 500 days they spent together, searching for what he did wrong. Marc Webb directed this Sundance selection.

A WOMAN IN BERLIN A German woman (Nina Hoss), reduced to desperate straits during the Soviet occupation of Berlin, enters into a tense relationship with a Russian officer (Evgeny Sidikhin). Max Färberböck (“Aimée & Jaguar”) wrote and directed from the nonfiction book published under the name “Anonyma.”

July 24

THE ANSWER MAN The author of a popular book on spirituality (Jeff Daniels) encounters a single mom (Lauren Graham) and a young man just out of rehab (Lou Taylor Pucci) who mistakenly believe that he knows all the answers to life’s problems. John Hindman wrote and directed.

BLISS From Turkey, Abdullah Oguz’s drama tells the story of a rape victim (Ozgu Namal) whose family demands she be sentenced to death to save their honor.

G-FORCE A 3-D blend of animation and live-action from the producer Jerry Bruckheimer; it’s about a team of highly trained guinea pigs (with the voices of Sam Rockwell, Tracy Morgan and Penélope Cruz) who work in a secret government program. Hoyt Yeatman directed.

GOTTA DANCE Dori Berinstein’s documentary tells the story of the New Jersey NetSationals, a hip-hop dance troupe for the New Jersey basketball team, made up of 13 seniors.

IN THE LOOP A hapless British minister for international development (Tom Hollander) sets off an international panic when he casually observes that war is “unforeseeable.” Armando Iannucci (the TV series “The Thick of It”) directed this mid-Atlantic comedy; with Peter Capaldi, James Gandolfini, Steve Coogan, Gina McKee, Mimi Kennedy and Anna Chlumsky.

ORPHAN A childless couple (Vera Farmiga and Peter Sarsgaard) adopt a 9-year-old girl (Isabelle Fuhrman) who may not be as innocent as she seems. Jaume Collet-Serra (of the 2005 remake of “House of Wax”) directs.

SABOR TROPICAL An American journalist (Matthew Leitch) travels to Panama to cover Carnival but in the process discovers some sobering truths about himself. Written and directed by Jorge Ameer. THE UGLY TRUTH A television host (Gerard Butler) with a reductivist view of male-female relationships offers dating advice to his producer (Katherine Heigl), who has her eyes on a sensitive doctor. Robert Luketic (“Legally Blonde”) directed; with Cheryl Hines and Kevin Connolly.
